title: Painting, Interior of Henry de Forest House, 1878
title_raw: Interior of Henry de Forest House
medium: Oil on canvas mounted on canvas
dimensions:
61.3 x 45.7 cm (24 1/8 in. x 18 in.)
Frame:  82 x 67.5 x 6.4 cm (32 5/16 x 26 9/16 x 2 1/2 in), approximate depth
creditline: Smithsonian American Art Museum, Museum purchase
gallery_text: De Forest’s first opportunity to work on an interior design project was for his parent’s home. It is also de Forest’s only documented interior prior to his travels in India. The parlor featured a door surround painted to resemble Damascus inlay work, a Satsuma vase on a Middle-Eastern taboret, a paisley shawl on a table in the rear room, and an abundance of oriental rugs. The year before this undertaking, de Forest joined the Society of Decorative Art, founded by interior designer Candace Wheeler to instruct women in handicraft professions. His mother, Julia Weeks de Forest, and his uncle, John A. Weeks, were also involved in the group; De Forest, Louis Comfort Tiffany, and Samuel Colman served as instructors.

Smithsonian American Art Museum, Museum purchase. 9.2012.1
